sections.section: This tutorial demonstrates a simple message flow that receives an HTTP message containing a set of employee records in a CSV format. The request body is line feed separated, with one row for each employee. Each row uses commas to separate the fields. The flow uses a Sequence node to insert a sequence number into each row. At the end of the message flow, all the data rows are added to an output file.
This tutorial requires an ACE integration node (or standalone server) which is associated with a local queue manager.

In IBM App Connect Enterprise, an application is a container for deployed resources such as message flows. This tutorial provides a single application, holding one message flow, and which references a shared library containing a DFDL message model which describes the CSV data format expected by the flow.

sections.section: When you click Import, one application and one shared library will be created in your workspace:
The application Sequence contains a message flow also named Sequence.
The shared library CommaSeparatedValues contains a DFDL model file named csv.xsd.

The message flow receives an HTTP message containing a set of employee records in a CSV format. The request body is line feed separated with one row for each employee. The HTTPInput node parses the input message. The Compute node then loops over the rows and propagates them one after another to the Sequence node, which inserts a sequence number into each row before the FileOutput node writes the records to an output file. To complete the flow, a summary message stating that processing is complete is returned to the requestor by the HTTPReply node.
Once you import the tutorial, the provided application is almost ready to be deployed and tested. However, before you do this, read the Prepare tab which describes preparing your deploy environment.

sections.section: The message flow in this tutorial uses a sequence node, which uses MQ storage queues to hold information about the state of in-flight messages. The storage queues are owned by the queue manager that is associated with the integration node or integration server. The instructions provided below assume the use of an integration node.

details.details: Create the default App Connect Enterprise queues in IBM MQ by completing the following steps:

Open the IBM App Connect Enterprise Console. If you don't already have one, create and start a queue manager:
crtmqm qmgr
strmqm qmgr

Next create the queues by typing the following command:
server\sample\wmq\iib_createqueues qmgr
where
qmgr is the queue manager name.
Create an integration node which is associated with the above queue manager by completing the following steps:

In the console window, create an integration node by typing the following command:
mqsicreatebroker TESTNODE -q qmgr

Start the integration node by typing the following command:
mqsistart TESTNODE

Create an integration server associated with the integration node by typing the following command:
mqsicreateexecutiongroup TESTNODE -e default

The FileOutput node's Basic property tab includes a Directory property which specifies where the output file should be written. This has been set to C:\IIB_Sequence_Tutorial_Output but you can change this to a value of your own choice. Create the directory on the file system of the machine where your runtime node resides.

sections.section: <h4>Use the Flow Exerciser to test the tutorial scenario

details.details: Drag and drop deploy the shared library named CommaSeparatedValues on to your integration server in the Integration Explorer view (by default shown in the bottom left corner of your Toolkit).
Click the Flow Exerciser icon to start testing the flow
Click the Send Message icon .
Select the saved message which has been provided, named InputMessage, and click Send. The message will be sent to the HTTPInput node.
The pop-up dialog will show the message has been sent and a response received stating Processing complete- each row has been given a sequence number and written to the output file.
After you close the dialog, the paths taken through the messageflow are highlighted. Click on the message icon on each connection to see how the tree has been updated by each node.

Finally, locate the output file in the directory which you configured on the earlier Prepare step). You will see that the output file has had sequence numbers inserted at the end of each row of data:
Department01,Smith,Robert,Brandon,1988-03-24,1
Department01,Johnson,John,Martin,1986-01-23,2
Department01,Jones,Arya,Cat,1986-02-19,3
Department01,Bonham,John,Henry,1948-05-31,4
Department01,Walters,Amanda,Louise,1966-08-01,5
